title: Right to Information (RTI)
description: You can request information from any government body under the RTI Act, 2005.
steps: Identify the public authority holding the information.
Write an RTI application in simple language mentioning the details you need.
Pay the prescribed fee (usually ₹10).
Submit it via post, online RTI portal, or in person.
Receive a reply within 30 days.

title: Right to Legal Aid
description: Free legal assistance is available for economically weaker sections under Article 39A.
steps: Check if you qualify under the income or category criteria.
Approach the nearest Legal Services Authority office.
Submit identity and income proof.
A lawyer will be assigned to represent you for free.

title: Right to Education
description: Children between 6–14 years have the right to free and compulsory education.
steps: Identify a government or government-aided school nearby.
Submit birth certificate or Aadhaar card for age proof.
Admission must be granted without charging any fees.
Ensure mid-day meals and textbooks are provided free.

title: Right to Vote
description: Every citizen above 18 years has the right to vote without discrimination.
steps: Ensure your name is in the electoral roll.
Carry your Voter ID or approved ID proof to the polling booth.
Follow the voting instructions given by the election officer.
Cast your vote using the EVM or ballot paper.

title: Right to Consumer Protection
description: You can file complaints against defective goods or poor services under the Consumer Protection Act.
steps: Collect all purchase bills and proof of defective product/service.
Approach the seller or service provider first.
If unresolved, file a complaint with the Consumer Commission.
Submit evidence and details of your grievance.

title: Right to Equality
description: No one can be discriminated against based on caste, religion, sex, or place of birth.
steps: Report any discrimination to the concerned authority.
Approach the Human Rights Commission if necessary.
Seek legal action through the courts for violation.

title: Right to Freedom of Speech
description: You can express your opinions freely while respecting reasonable restrictions by law.
steps: Speak or write your views responsibly without hate speech.
Ensure you do not incite violence or defamation.
Use media, public forums, or social platforms legally.

title: Right to File FIR
description: Police must register an FIR for any cognizable offence; refusal is illegal.
steps: Visit the nearest police station.
Provide details of the offence orally or in writing.
Request a copy of the FIR with an official stamp.
If refused, approach higher police authorities or file online.

title: Right to Legal Representation
description: Every accused person has the right to consult and be represented by a lawyer.
steps: Contact a lawyer of your choice.
If unable to afford, request free legal aid from the Legal Services Authority.
Meet your lawyer regularly to discuss your case.

title: Right Against Illegal Detention
description: You must be produced before a magistrate within 24 hours of arrest.
steps: Ask the police to inform your family immediately.
Demand to see the arrest warrant if applicable.
Request legal representation.
Insist on being presented before a magistrate within 24 hours.

title: Right to Privacy
description: Your personal information is protected under the right to privacy as a fundamental right.
steps: Avoid sharing sensitive personal data unnecessarily.
Report misuse of your personal information to authorities.
Seek legal remedy if your privacy is violated.

title: Right to Health Services
description: You can access basic health facilities and emergency treatment without advance payment.
steps: Visit the nearest government hospital or health centre.
In emergencies, request immediate treatment without payment.
Escalate to health authorities if denied services.

title: Right to Environment
description: You have the right to a clean and healthy environment.
steps: Report pollution or environmental hazards to local authorities.
Participate in community clean-up drives.
File complaints with the Pollution Control Board if needed.

title: Right to Work in a Safe Workplace
description: Every worker has the right to a safe working environment under labour laws.
steps: Report unsafe conditions to your employer.
Request safety equipment and training.
Complain to the labour department if unsafe conditions persist.

title: Right to Maternity Leave
description: Female employees are entitled to 26 weeks of paid maternity leave.
steps: Inform your employer in advance about your maternity leave.
Submit medical proof of pregnancy if required.
Ensure salary is paid during the leave period.

title: Right Against Child Labour
description: Children under 14 cannot be employed in hazardous occupations.
steps: Report instances of child labour to the police or labour department.
Call child helpline number 1098.
Assist in rehabilitating the child through NGOs.

title: Right to Minimum Wages
description: Workers are entitled to be paid at least the state-notified minimum wage.
steps: Know the current minimum wage rates for your state.
Keep proof of work hours and payment records.
Complain to the labour department if underpaid.

title: Right to Safe Food
description: FSSAI ensures the safety and quality of food products sold in India.
steps: Check FSSAI license number on packaged food.
Report unsafe food to the Food Safety Department.
Keep the sample for testing if needed.

title: Right to Safe Travel
description: Passengers have the right to safety and compensation in case of accidents.
steps: Report unsafe travel conditions to transport authorities.
In case of accidents, claim compensation through the carrier.
Keep tickets and travel proof for filing claims.

title: Right to Receive Wages on Time
description: Employers must pay wages without unlawful deductions.
steps: Track salary payment dates.
Raise the issue with HR or employer first.
Complain to the labour commissioner if unresolved.

title: Right to be Heard in Consumer Court
description: You can approach the consumer court for grievances within 2 years of the incident.
steps: File your complaint in the appropriate consumer form.
Attach all proofs of purchase and grievance.
Attend hearings and present your case clearly.

title: Right to Free Police Help
description: Police cannot refuse help in emergencies and cannot demand bribes.
steps: Call 100 or visit the nearest police station.
Record the incident details if possible.
Report refusal or misconduct to higher police authorities.

title: Right to Fair Trial
description: Every person accused of a crime has the right to a fair and public trial.
steps: Ensure you have legal representation.
Attend all court hearings.
Present your evidence and witnesses.
Appeal the decision if necessary.

title: Right Against Dowry
description: Demanding or giving dowry is a criminal offence.
steps: Report dowry demands to the police immediately.
File a complaint under the Dowry Prohibition Act.
Seek protection through the women’s helpline.

title: Right to Protection from Domestic Violence
description: The law protects against physical, emotional, and economic abuse.
steps: Call the domestic violence helpline or 181.
File a complaint with the Protection Officer.
Seek shelter or legal protection orders if needed.

title: Right to Senior Citizen Protection
description: Senior citizens can claim maintenance and protection under the Maintenance Act.
steps: Approach the Maintenance Tribunal for claims.
Seek police help in case of abuse or harassment.
Contact senior citizen helplines for assistance.

title: Right to Free Education for Girls
description: Many states offer free education schemes for girl children.
steps: Check eligibility criteria for state schemes.
Submit necessary documents to the school.
Claim free books, uniforms, and tuition benefits.

title: Right to Refund
description: Consumers can claim a full refund for defective or undelivered goods.
steps: Approach the seller with proof of purchase.
If refused, file a consumer complaint.
Submit product photographs and payment details.

title: Right to Lodge Online Complaints
description: Citizens can file complaints via government portals like CPGRAMS.
steps: Visit the official grievance portal.
Fill in the complaint form with details.
Track the status of your complaint online.

title: Right to Emergency Services
description: No hospital can refuse emergency treatment regardless of payment status.
steps: Call 108 or visit the nearest hospital.
Request immediate treatment in emergencies.
Report denial of treatment to health authorities.
